A law of composition on a set $M$ is a map from $M \times M$ to $M$. It is characterized by the assignment $(a, b) \longmapsto a \cdot b$ for $(a, b) \in M \times M$, and in many cases, the image of a given pair $(a, b)$ is written as a "product" $a \cdot b$ or $ab$.

Given a normal subgroup $N \subset G$ of a group $G$, the factor group or the residue class group of $G$ modulo $N$, denoted $G / N$, is the group formed by the set of left cosets of $N$ in $G$ with the group operation defined by $(aN) \cdot (bN) = (ab)N$ for $a, b \in G$.

For a polynomial f=
sum a_i X^i in R[X] with deg f=n 
geq 0, the coefficient a_n is called the leading coefficient. If a_n=1, the polynomial is called monic.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.

Let $R$ be an integral domain and $p \in R$ a nonzero nonunit. $p$ is called irreducible if a factorization of type $p=x y$ with $x, y \in R$ implies $x \in R^{*}$ or $y \in R^{*}$. Furthermore, $p$ is called reducible if it is not irreducible.
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
A separable polynomial is a polynomial that has distinct roots in its splitting field, i.e., all roots are simple.
The extension field $L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if every element $\alpha \in L$ is algebraic over $K$.
An algebraic closure of a field $K$, denoted as $\bar{K}$, is an algebraically closed field that is algebraic over $K$.
A splitting field $L$ of a polynomial $f \\(in K[X]\\) with coefficients in a field $K$ is a field extension $L / K$ where the polynomial $f$ splits into linear factors.

A subgroup H of a finite group G is called a p-Sylow subgroup if H is a p-group such that p does not divide the index (G: H). This means there exist integers k, m in N satisfying ord H=p^k, as well as ord G=p^k m, where p does not divide m.
A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: An algebraic closure of a field (ID: 8) is a specific type of algebraic field extension (ID: 7) where the field is not only algebraic over the base field but also algebraically closed.
A splitting field of a polynomial (ID: 9) is a specific type of algebraic field extension (ID: 7) where the field extension is such that a given polynomial splits into linear factors.
